reviews.review_text: Absolution draws a hard line between itself and the previous 4 installments of the game without alienating die hard fans of this franchise. Absolution is far more cerebral than it's predecessors. The storyline is multifaceted and weaves together a plot that focuses on exposing 47's ambitions, strengths, and flaws without making him appear weak or whiny; he is still the ultimate badass, but much more human and believable. Absolution shows a more realistic and approachable 47; one I, and I assume others, can easily identify with. This game really develops Hitman's character on a much deeper level than previously attempted.  The movements of 47 are very swift and responsive. In fact, many of 47's movements can be compared to how Sam Fisher's movements are in the Splinter Cell games, which means players can now access cover and look around at a 360 angle. I would also compare the sneaking around to the Metal Gear games, as well. In this game, there are just SO many ways to go about taking out a primary target. On one level, I was given the option to take out a target in 12 different ways. That way could be by taking him out, wearing various disguises, taken him out quietly, poisoning his food, blowing his car up or taking him out with guns blazing. Not to mention, players can get reward for doing so, which enhances the replay value of this game.  The AI has been greatly improved. Characters interact with their environment, situations, and the actions of 47 in many fascinating ways now. Characters generally still have predetermined paths but they can now be interrupted, altered, redirected, and distracted to allow 47 to accomplish his objectives. This really makes a difference in the game play. You no longer have to memorize guards paths or actions, rather you can now change the course of events by affecting the characters in any given situation to gain access to your targets.  All in all this game is by far the best adaptation of Hitman yet. I highly recommend it. You can play this game and still feel comfortable without having ever played any previous versions.

There are numerous items of great value in Hitman: Absolution which highlight the excellent quality value, such a good longevity, which stood at least on a dozen hours abundant in relation to the ability of the player and the difficulty level chosen, a significant able to challenge general, a technical realization of good quality and a judicious mix of structural sandbox and stealth. At the same time we can not ignore some design choices rather abnormal and tend to tarnish the feeling of enjoyment experienced by the player, such as artificial intelligence sometimes too deficient for stealth gameplay or atypical management bailouts. Nevertheless Hitman: Absolution is the worthy heir to a series that has always represented the best that the genre of stealth could offer and its beauty lies in the nonlinearity that distinguishes its gameplay: the ability to freely choose how and when to act, who kill, kill, where and how to do it is always anchored in the hands of the player. And this is obviously an element that can give great satisfaction.

As of 2016, it has been 10 years since the release of Hitman Blood money, the game defined the Hitman style of play and is regarded as one of the best stealth games of all time, to which I agree. 6 years later we now have Hitman Absolution developed by IO interactive and published by Square Enix, is it better than Blood money? or does it fall flat? Let's start with the plot.  Hitman Absolution kicks off right after the Hitman book: Hitman Damnation by author Raymond Benson, which took place after Blood money. Agent 47 (The main character of the Hitman Franchise) is told by the new head of the ICA: Benjamen Travis, to assasinate 47's former handler Diana Burnwood. When 47 shoots Diana, she tells 47 to save a girl by the name of Victoria as her last dying wish. I thought the plot was pretty well done   Let's get this out of the way first, the game is absolutely gorgeous with highly detailed locations, great lighting, sharp textures, great character models and animations. However, there is a bit too much bloom, especially 47's bald head.  The gameplay mostly consists of you having to get from one end of a level to the other while trying not to get spotted by enemies. Some missions have you killing a certain target within an area and these sections are by far the best parts of the game. You have a variety of ways to kill your target which goes from using electricity, blow up, grind, burn alive, blow up, stab, and yeah you get the idea. If you're not the sneaky type and want to shoot your way through the game's serveral chapers, that is also an option, the gunplay is perhaps one of the most tight I've played in a third person shooter. In each level there is a item you can find called evidence, which can be used to boost your score, and this takes me to the new feature for the Hitman franchise: the points system.  In almost every level, you will be scored on how you completed a level, such as losing points if you had to kill an NPC and didn't hide the body, killed the target in a creative way, lose points when spotted, etc. When you got enough points, you can learn assassin techniques which can be used to make 47 more efficient, such as reducing the time it takes to reload your gun, run faster, more health, and you get the picture. A returning feature is the much loved disguise system since the first Hitman game, although it works a bit different here.  If you find a disguise in a level, you can then wear it and move among the enemy, however it does not shield you fully from the enemy. If an enemy or civilian sees you while wearing their clothing, they will take longer to realize that you don't belong here and will investigate, however the other people in different clothing will not find you suspicious. This new system definitely works in my opinion, and if it was like blood money, the game would be almost impossible to fail.  A new mode to the series is contracts mode, you pick one of the many levels in the game, look around and then mark 3 targets, kill them how you want, and put it online to see who can do the same hit more efficiently. This mode is probably the closest you'll get to Blood Money gameplay and is definitely a mode that shouldn't be avoided. When you complete a contract in contracts mode you earn money which can be used to buy upgrades for your guns, buy disguises, and more guns.  The sound design of the game is top notch, the music is well done even without Jesper Kyd, and the voice acting is superb, especially David Bateson who voices 47 who does an exceptional job.  The A.I. in this game is also pretty good, they will actively search for you if you are hiding and know when to take cover during fire fights. Although there were still parts where they did act strange, such as ignoring dead bodies and shooting in the wrong direction.   In the end, Hitman Absolution is an excellent edition to the Hitman franchise and shouldn't be overlooked just because it's not that much like Blood money. I even think Absolution is just as good as Blood money.  Hitman Absolution is beautifully executed.

A 'meh' recommendation. Ever play a game that just drips with high production values and class, but you still don't like it? That's how I feel about Hitman: Absolution. I realize that it's something plenty of people will enjoy. I just didn't. Do I think it's worth picking up? Sure, if it's on sale. And you're bored.  If that sounds like I'm getting ready to drop some grade-A hate, I'm not. At least, I don't want to. There is so much about Hitman: Absolution that just reeks of care and attention. The graphics are amazing. Not necessarily a reason to buy a game, but they are. The voice acting is superb (Keith Carradine and Powers Boothe? Hell yes!). The soundtrack works incredibly well, giving an almost Bond-esque ambiance without ever getting too loud. While some levels are occasionally re-used, there are a lot of different locations and settings. And as far as the story goes, I felt incredibly close to Agent 47 (he's quite sympathetic, despite his stoicism). Sneaking from cover to cover feels fluid and natural. Weapons are deadly (headshots are a breeze with the Silverballers).   So what's my problem? Most of the levels are claustrophobic (the opening Chinatown level and the cornfield level are exceptions). The paths through the levels are restrictive. And some levels don't even bother to hide their linearity (final rooftop level, among many others). There's no way to level-up Agent 47. Upgrades are unlocked based upon how high of a score you received upon completing a mission. But the points system clearly favors a specific path – even penalizing for non-target knockouts. I was never a fan of the Assassin's Creed games' “full synchonization” mechanic either, but this just ticked me off. There is no loadout customization; you start every mission with choke-wire and (after you unlock them) the Silverballers. Other weapons are acquired by finding them or picking them up from dead enemies – but it doesn't matter, because you'll be back to the piano wire and Silverballers once the next mission starts.   Disguises are actually not a problem; there are plenty of them around. Using them is sometimes strange, though. If planning to ghost through a police station, DON'T try to use a police uniform as a disguise. Why? Because if a cop gets too close to you, he'll detect that you're not a real policeman. Makes sense, I suppose. But in a level crawling with police, disguising as a police officer becomes a questionable strategy – which seems counter-intuitive to me. Much better to knock out a homeless person and take his disguise, since the officers won't detect you. But then, dressed as a homeless person, you won't be able to enter restricted areas without attracting attention anyway. Several times I just lost patience and started taking innocent people out to facilitate progress – and several times got embroiled in a full-on gun battle. Which actually wasn't that bad. If you're careful, 47 has a ton of health, and headshots are 1-hit kills. Add in the deadly Instinct combat mode, which has elements of the VATS system from Fallout, and 47 becomes an absolute wrecking ball of death.  There were some great moments, though. Ghosting through the flaming warehouse while troopers searched the premises was a thrill. Heading deeper underground through a mining facility with guards everywhere was a delicate game of cat-and-mouse. And trying to take out three henchmen in Chinatown with throngs of people everywhere was easily the most enjoyment I had. Somehow I thought every level would feature that amount of variety and detail, and I'm disappointed that (to me) it didn't. Recommended because Hitman: Absolution is polished and does what it sets out to do, but ultimately it's only a mediocre game that is sprinkled with some great levels.

Uninstall and play Blood Money. If you've already played Blood Money, play it again.   It's hard to find any redeeming quality for Hitman Absolution, it is a passable stealth game - but the worst Hitman game to date. The overhauls to the disguises, rating system and the disjointed checkpointed levels immedietly kill the greatest qualities of the previous entries in the franchise. There is no freedom here, the levels are carefully presented and split into brief and disjointed sections via checkpoints to ensure no exploration or creativity in approach is possible so your objectives. Not that any organic and non-linear approach is possible when an extremely large portion of Absolution is literally moving from point A to point B.

From the vacuum sealed mission area, to the awkward new instincs system. This game does not live up to as a Blood Money sucessor.  The new 'instincs' meter is an interesting concept, but implemented in the worst of ways. Specifically the costumes/disguises side of it. Back in BM (Blood Money), disguises would give you certain access to specific areas, within reason. Taking the opera house as an example, dressed as a cop you could access some backstage areas. As one of the target's priviate secuirty guard, you gained even more access, etc. The disguises had a certain limited usefulness based on where you were going to use it.  Now, I have no idea if the designers were having issues about 'how' to implement diguises in Absolution, but this whole 'skill meter' that goes down whenever someone even looks your way in disguise is a bit silly. In the very first mission, following the tutorial. You have to kill some guy in a tiny market, packed with people.  One of the ways to deal with the situation is to steal a poisonous fish to use it's poison against the target. Thing is, the fish is on a counter within a cooking stall. Even if you have a chef outfit, you need to hold down your 'instinc' ability so that you don't get spotted by the other cooks. Even though I was holding it down, seems when you pick up the fish that still triggers 'suspicion'. And then I had the cook chase me down until she called security...  The feeling of stealth and being 'mixed' in with the crowd is just completely ruined. The tutorial section gives out this sad mechanic when you have to use disguises a few times, but each time you still need to hold down the 'instincs' ability to not get your cover blown. And the AI's range for getting suspicious is ludicrous. If at least they would have kept it for 'face to face' encounters. IE, if you get to close to a guard he could call you up, and you'd have to use your instincs to come up with some BS answer/cover story or your cover would be blown. I mean the fact that 47's 'defense' is to lower his head and put his hand on his forehead... really? Doesn't that make you look even more suspicious... ugh.  As many others pointed out, the lack of mission 'preperation' is kind of annoying. You get dropped into a level, and most of the 'weapons' you need to find scattered around the location... I know that in BM you could spend money to get special weapons dropped for you within a mission area, but this one just feels totally wrong. Finding remote explosives in a crate of fruit for no specific reason, feels wrong.  And although there are numerous ways to 'kill your target', many of them end up causing level wide alarm. And you 'need to' clear all security forces, or so it seems, before leaving a mission area... Very entertaining... Not really. If you look on youtube, many peoplel who showcase killing alternatives, do so and end the video shortly after the level wide alarm is triggered. You still get the achievement though...  Blood money offered way more flexibility, and diversity of the way you disposed of your targets. And not all of them were on a razor's edge. In Absolution, maybe the later missions get better, but the first 'real' 'mission feals claustrophobic, extremely limited in actual stealh options (massively hindered by this new instinc system).  The overhaul experience feels too different to create any meaningful parralel with BM, a game that I love and have reinstalled and replayed numerous times. The level of freedom gives almost each playthrough a different feeling, and opportunity to explore different parts of the level of ways to accomplish your goal.  Absolution falls so flat on the countless aspects that made Blood money the success it is. I don't want to sound dismissive of the team, but it's almost like someone drew up a list of good and bads from BM, and instead of sending the good list to the dev team, they sent the list of bad things to them.  They promised a much more different experience in the upcoming new hitman game, but I'm going to be as weary as I was with this one, and wait for it to come on sale. And I'm not talking 15% off here, more like 75%+.

Soooo...I already played this game, entirely. Just to be sure I wasn't missing something. I did this on PS3.Then a friend of mine decided: 'hey you should stream this game. Here's a key for the pc version'. And I never streamed it. Why? It sucks on so many levels, but especially in two areas.  -First:  In terms of mechanics, the game is not well designed at all. And I'm not talking about the linearity of the level-design, though that is a big step back compared to the perfect Blood Money (perfect on that point at least). No, the main idea is to resolve an incoherence of the series (the fact that when dressed as a cop, no cop will tell that you look suspicious) by creating this 47 'sense'. It is a bad bad bad decision. In theory, well balanced and polished, this would be an ok solution to a 'non'-problem. But in execution, this gauge means that you can't be dressed as the type of character that is the most seen in the level, because you'll be unmasked in seconds by these guys, except if you use that sense gauge that emptied itself way too quickly. In lower difficulty settings it can work okay, but when in pro mode, some missions are just stupidly difficult to perform a 'silent assassin' rank. Except if you play the game like a Conviction ripoff. That means that, in a HITMAN game, you spend 80% of your time crouching behind counters, taking down people that are not relevant to your objectives...when you should be proudly crossing entire rooms just walking, dressed as a clown, a priest or a bodyguard. The essence of Hitman is to be hidden in plain sight, and that mechanic f-ed it up.  The worst thing is: it is not even a good Conviction ripoff. The game doesn't know how to balance this modern predator stealth kind of gameplay, that we all played from Arkham Asylum to Human Revolution with the Hitman type of infiltration. And that gives us a level-design and NPC placement that satisfes no ends.  -Second:  ...and foremost should I say, Absolution is incredibly vulgar and idiotic. And I know, being a fan of this series since the second one, that there is some poor taste jokes in previous episodes. But overall, I think the tone of it all, the focus on the themes rather than the characters, and the fact that the story never really was a focus of the game, merely a way to introduce nice game-design ideas (that be cool to make a hit on a classy boat! let's find some story about drug dealers on the Mississippi river!) gave opportunities to take it as a juvenile way to contextualise the gameplay, and it kept intact the elegant nature of the main character. Absolution can't stop putting 'story' in the game. The cutscenes are longer, the game is more focused on that, rather than giving the player a good challenge, and by god why is there so much bad language in this game, and why all the childish sex elements? The Saints are the farther the series as ever been from good taste or even a bit of maturity. That doesn't make the game cool, or mature. It just looks like either an idiot who wants to tell a story with edgy characters, or a kid who wants to look like a bad*ss. Plus, I swear, the story makes no sense, and from beginning to end, you can pinpoint a major incoherence in each cutscene.   TL;DR: The game is poorly game-designed and doesn't know if it wants to be a predator-stealth game, like the Arkham series or Conviction (that were previously released) of if it wants to kinda stick to the Hitman formula. It satisfies non of these two game-designs and tries to resolve an incoherence by creating even more incohenrences. Plus the game talks to you like if you were a complete idiot and use bad language in place of good writting to tell a poorly put together story.   AVOID. Play Contracts, Blood Money or the 2016's Hitman for the real deal. This one is just pretty looking and insults your intelligence.

Absolution would have been a great game if the developers took out the disguise detection system with its giant yellow arrows of omnipresence.  If you want to experience levels of high blood pressure you should buy this game.

I've been a long-time fan of this series since the first installment by Eidos, Hitman: Codename 47. It's gotten a lot better with each subsequent installment, and this is no exception.  This game defines what it means to use stealth. Much like Splinter Cell, or Thief, this game rewards you for your patience, and puts it to the test with each stage. The game isn't particularly long either, with each mission area being fairly short, with minimal objectives to complete, but it's the time it takes to wait for that guard to finish his route, or the two civilians holding a conversation to move along that makes the game long and enjoyable.  The game's basic plot is you're given a mission to eliminate an Agency rat and through the act of actually getting to your target, you learn there's something bigger at play, and you defy your commanding officer, setting a string of events in motion that will put your will to the test. You're thrown into the game with a minimalistic prologue/tutorial that tells you the basics of sneaking around and causing distractions, killing, subduing, hiding bodies, etc... and then before the mission is over, you're introduced to the rating system. A system that awards points for positive actions (objectives, hiding bodies, evidence, silent kills, etc...) and penalizes you for naughty actions (getting spotted, killing/pacifying non targets, killing civilians, etc...). The goal is to maximize your score on each mission by completing challenges and completing your objectives in a multitude of (creative) ways. The best rating you can get on a mission is Silent Assassin, whereby you complete all your objectives only killing your intended target(s), and not getting spotted. This is the most difficult to pull off, but it makes it all that much more fun. The multiple challenges that you can complete are also presented in such a way that it requires multiple passes through a mission before you can claim them all (many are mutually exclusive), so the incentive is to keep thinking of new ways to win. The one downside to this system though, is that when you complete a challenge, it stays for good, so reloading a checkpoint is enough to give you the credit to complete the other challenges without a full playthrough.  The missions are tough and well scripted. The dialog and the musical score is top notch, though there are some lines that are pretty corny. The character cast is great and it can be sometimes hard to follow who's who, but they are all likeable (or dispicable). The game offers a wide spectrum of difficulty, whereby the harder you go, the tougher (and more plentiful) the enemies get, the more aware they are, and you get to use less of your 'instinct', a skill that allows you to see interactive objects and enemy trails, as well as the ability to blend in using a disguise. The hardest difficulty is the toughest enemies, highly reactive, and no interface. The only other game I've seen that done with is Call of Juarez: Gunslinger (another great game). Good luck 47!  It also sports a contract mode, which is sort of like on-line competition where you complete user-created contract missions for money to increase your stats. It's a pretty slick system.  Check this game out, you won't be disappointed.

'Hide in plain sight' - thats what they said in the trailer.  Boy I was excited about the game - the very first game I preordered, because it looked gorgeous and the delevopers seemed like they knew what people expect from a hitman game.  Like a child I didn't get to bed just to play it the second it was released. And for the first few seconds I was overwhelmed. It look good, the story didn't seem particulary well but interesting enough.  And then it all went down... Lets go to the positives first: - Beatiful! You have to give them credit for that - Contracts seemed like a good idea - Shooting mechanics are quite good, covering works well  - Some nice ways to eliminate your targets - Kinda good stealth game - Very good level design (visually)  CONS: - An absolutely broken checkpoint system. It doesn't even save who you killed. Everything came back to live afterwards. Everything you tried to buid up to vanished.  - Disguise system is broken. Others have mentioned it. Hide in plain sight is only possible if the enemies are far away and you really really hurry up. Everyone wearing the same disguise can spot you. Like hundreds of cops would know each other on a personal level if they are hunting for a suspect. This was the point that killed it for me... Instead of thinking of clever ways of how to acquire a disguise that will get you through the next section they are utterly useless, you still have to hunker down in cover... Wait for painfully long periods of time until some NPC has finished the dialog to continue. Because, well, you wear the same clothes as him and the checkpoint is placed when they start talking, not when they are finished. Wonderful! Instinct lets you put your hand in front of your face for a short period of time because well... f***, thats why. Doesn't make any sense. - Very restricted areas. There are magic doors that you close behind you and no one will come through the door - ever. The level is divided in independent sections that share nothing between them. - The story gets really dumb and embarassing. They wanted to center it around our protagonist. And they could have made so much good with it, instead it turns quite obnoxious, weird and unbelievable... - Killing in cut scenes. You might have heard that. It doesn't happen often, but it is odd enough that they even think about that. Worse than the killing in cut scene is that the enemy is being killed IN FRONT OF DOZENDS OF BYSTANDERS which is exactly what Hitman is NOT about. Ridiculous  Bottom line is: If you expect a hitman like game, don't get this, not on sale, not ever. You are most likely going to be severly dissapointed. It is bad as a hitman game, they stripped it of almost everything that made it unique and interesting and not only dumbed down the gameplay to make it more accessible, but dumbed down the gameplay for no apparent reason because it actually makes it LESS accessible (other than perhaps lazyness when it comes to programming (I've been there)).  If you are looking for a stealth game where you can calmy time your next moves and know nothing about hitman, or hated the previous games, this might be a pleasant surprise for you. Then you should get it. It's a catch for 5€..    I get that things need to change to keep a series interesting. And the previous games had their flaws. Hitman: Absolution does nothing by halves. When the game is good, it's fantastic and borderline brilliant. But when the game is BAD, woah boy, is it BAD. Missions are generally broken down into two different types; being given targets to assassinate by any means necessary, and Metal Gear Solid-esque sneaking through larger levels to get to the exit. The former can be absolutely stellar; you have to plan takedowns of other targets to get disguises to get close enough to your target (preferably without getting caught, as the best laid plans will understandably get torn asunder if someone sees you moving a body), and are then given a variety of methods to take your mark out, ranging from doing it personally with a gun or garotte wire, or, my personal favourite, using various parts of the environment to set up 'accidental kills', like framing your target so he gets shot by police, setting a live wire to where they urinate in an alley in order to electrocute them, or less subtle methods like causing a crane's hook to come undone and crushing them with its contents.  Unfortunately, where the game falls apart is in the long stealth sections that make up the rest of the game. There's very few checkpoints, it's almost impossible to shake suspicion once you've lingered in an NPCs line of sight for too long, even while disguised, and with few exceptions (like one case where you can throw the police off your trail by dropping the body from someone else's murder into their line of sight), they feel very uninspired. Worse of all the AI is very buggy at times; I've been spotted through solid walls, had would-be victims magically turn around at random despite never going so in the previous dozen or so attempts, and on at least three occasions had to completely restart a level because an NPC spawned right in front of a checkpoint, facing me. Worst of all, checkpoints DON'T save progress between game sessions, meaning if you crash or have to exit for whatever reason, you have to start the entire section from the beginning.  There's a recipe for a truly unmatched stealth game here; if Hitman: Absolution had focused more on the actual 'hits' and less on the horrendous stealth sections, it could have been darn near perfect. Unfortunately, those are diamonds in the rough, and there's a heck of a lot of rough to sift through. Thankfully the game's multiplayer 'Contracts' mode, where players can set challenges for other players to beat by doing those actions in the in-game setting, provides a steady stream of decent diversions and while the stealth sections heavily bog down the early stages of the game, much of the later game brings the game back to form.  All told Absolution slips by with a recommendation, but with a lot of caveats. Sadly beyond Contracts mode you HAVE to endure the lousy stealth levels at least once to get to the good stuff, meaning those without a lot of patience for that sort of thing had best look elsewhere. The meat of the game is in replayability; thankfully replays break chapters up into sections that allow you to bypass the worst parts of them if you see fit.  I really, really hope that the next Hitman game learns from Absolutions' flaws and continues to polish its gems. For now, Absolution is fun-- just very flawed fun.

I picked this game up for 3.99 €, as several friends said they liked it.  At first, it felt very avarage. Clunky character animations with poor transitions, cheap sound effects, barely-interesting story, that feels disconnected from the gameplay itself. But I can handle that.  The game ran very poorly, despite the fact that the graphics lack detail and enviroments are small. Now I can handle playing a game on low graphics without complaining, it's okay. Gameplay is what matters, in the end.  It crashed twice during first mission, and I lost progress. Then it crashed later, somewhere around 2nd or 3rd mission. Iam okay with that though. Few crashes at beginning, and one rare in the middle, I can live with that. No problem.  I continue playing, Iam getting more and more bored. It became very mediocre. And as I played even more, I actually became frustrated because of certain game mechanics, I'll list them here:  1) Trespassing zones - most of the time, there's no way to tell that you're heading to an area that's restricted. Worse, once you enter the restricted zone, the people around start getting angry very quickly. Too quickly, and there's no time to turn around.  2) Disguise system - great concept in general, but very poorly executed. You've certainly seen tens of movies, or heard several stories, that involved a spy who masked himself as a guard/policeman/mercenary, and used this disguise to make his way through restricted areas. In this game? It doesn't work, because when you are under disguise, people with same clothes as you will get suspicious very quickly and will attack you. I find it ridiculous, because for example, when you silently snap the neck of a policeman, and take the police uniform and wear it, other cops will become agressive within seconds if you pass by. To get benefit from the disguise system, you actually have to do the  opposite , you need to find the rarest clothes possible - so the chance of meeting a person with same clothes is minimal.  3) Mission design - everything I mentioned above could be solved if this particular problem disappeared. The design of levels, placement of characters, their routes and view angles, and the placement of flank routes, is just wrong. It feels as if the levels were designed for a first-person shooter game. Did I mention first-person shooters? This Hitman game actually has a few Michael Bay scenes, and they are a complete miss. They don't match the pace of the game, they don't match the atmosphere, and they set a wrong type of mood for the upcoming mission.    In the end, I'd give this game 5/10, maybe even 4/10. For stealth, the Splinter Cell series feels better in every aspect. I feel bad for this negative review, because it seems like everyone loves this game, but if I wanted to post a positive review, I'd have to lie.  If you are reading this review, and still decide to purchase the game - and you will discover that you like it, Iam happy for you, and wish I could say the same.

Apart from some obvious flaws, this is a nice addition to the Hitman franchise.  I'm just going to say right off the bat that this is a pretty fun Hitman game. As a franchise it should have died with the very first Hitman game. While the original game had fans, I have to say it is one of the worst games I have played. The premise is not particularly interesting. Subsequent Hitman games have improved a great deal on the original but have always had shortcomings, for example, the second Hitman game had some really bad AI bugs which meant that you could quetly walk behind someone who is asking for for ID and politely strangle them. Some of the levels were tedious or pointless etc. So when considering this Hitman game, it is no different.  There are some really interesting ideas in this game that could have been so great but were poorly implemented. For example, hand to hand combat is basically the same 2 animations repeated over and over. this is especially odd considering the H2H was put on display in one particular level that has you in a bar room brawl. It is obvious that 47 is proficient in Karate but the moves on display quickly become a bore. It is also difficult to randomly engage an enemy in H2H. I don't expect it to be on par with Batman: AC but a little effort in this area could have gone a long way.  The other interesting but badly implemented idea is the focus skill. It is basically a rip off from Max Payne with a slight difference, the game almost pauses and you can pick your targets, ready for execution, then push a button and 47 will quickly dispatch a large number of foes. This skill is also put on show in another level that has you doing target practice. However this skill lacks the flare and showmanship of Max Payne, making this 'skill' feel more like a cheat. It takes the enjoyment out of dispatching enemies, especially on the PC where aiming is done with precision on the mouse.  Aside from these issues I found the game enjoyable. The story was a little strange though. 47 seems conflicted about being a hitman, but his pysche doesn't lend itself to those feelings. He isn't haunted by the people he has killed, he also has no moral qualms about killing a friend, because those are his orders after all. Aside from this though, the story is logical, believeable and simple. 47's journey to the end of the game is also highly varied. *spoiler* I absolutely loved the corn field level.  Depending on how you play the game, 47's brutality is on show, a ruthless and lethal killer who is pretty much untouchable.  Graphics: Superb use of the Unreal engine with some nice tweaks like tessalation which brings a new level of realness to 47's dome.  Sound: Atmospheric and functional.  Overall I would say it is worth the asking price, but as with all Hitman games, expect flaws.

Hitman: Absolution is a stealth video game developed by IO Interactive and published by Square Enix. Its the Fifth game in Hitman series. The game was released on 20 November 2012.  Story:- In the aftermath of Hitman: Blood Money, Diana Burnwood, Agent 47's handler with the International Contract Agency, suddenly goes rogue, carrying out a catastrophic sabotage that includes publicly exposing the Agency.The Agency reforms under Agent Benjamin Travis; Travis assigns 47 to kill Diana and bring Victoria, a teenage girl in her care, to the Agency.rather than executing her, comforts the dying Diana, who gives him a letter and asks him to keep Victoria safe from the Agency.47 hides Victoria at a Catholic orphanage somewhere in Chicago and contacts an International Contracts Agency (ICA) informant named Birdie, who asks him to kill a wealthy gangster nicknamed The King of Chinatown before he'll play ball. After eliminating him, 47 meets with Birdie, who briefs him about Blake Dexter, the CEO of Dexter Industries, who may have more information on Victoria. As payment, 47 is forced to give his signature Silverballers to Birdie.  Plot twist:-  in other words I'll simply say that 47 was Betrayed by the agency. it was the agency who was using us.   you will find your answers when you play the game.  I recommend the game.   Game-play:- the game is played from a third-person perspective and takes place primarily in the United States, mainly around the city of Chicago, Illinois, and the fictional town of Hope in South Dakota. The player controls Agent 47, a master hitman. Players may use pistols, bottles or bricks, assault rifles, shotguns, fiber-wire, or steel pipes, against enemies if opting for the action oriented approach, or avoid enemies all together, not being seen, using disguises, blending in the environment, and only attacking the set target, if using the stealth oriented approach. Agent 47 also has the 'Instinct' ability that lets the player monitor enemies more easily.There are also environmental ways to kill or distract individuals; players can use poison to spike coffee, pull switches to make a disco ball fall and break, cause a massive explosion at a gas station, pull a switch to cause scaffolding to fall down, cause fires, or set off fireworks. Players complete chapters in order to progress through the story. The player journeys to a mansion, library, strip club, gun store, wrestling arena, courthouse, and hotel, during the story    The game introduces an on-line option to the series, 'Contracts', where players can create their own missions for other players to complete.Players choose one of the areas in the game and modify it to create a different level. Players change the location of items, remove items, or add items, choose an objective or add a target, add a time limit, or choose which areas of the location are inaccessible and vice versa. Oh, Hitman Absolution..where do I start? After 43 hours of trying to get the 'perfect' score, according to the scoring system of course, I finally beat this.. (terribly) flawed 'masterpiece'. Hitman Absolution, could've been the best Hitman, as of previous Hitman game, IO fix some 'annoyance' in previous title, refining existing feature, and adding new one to keep it fresh and open up new feature. That's exactly what Absolution did, but along the way, they implementing some 'questionable' (and sometimes rather terrible) changes to the games, preventing it from becoming the best Hitman ever created, hell.. at some moment I feel like rating Absolution my 4th favorite Hitman game (my least favorite was the first one),   Well, just let's just go on with the actual review:   Graphic: 9/10      + Gorgeous! I love the attention in detail this game shows, I really like the atmosphere and tone. It looks really cinematic. And talking about cinematic, IO's presentation has gone up by 300% in Absolution. From the map detail and cinematic, it has a top notch presentation. Hitman Absolution is a downright nice game to look at. Oh, and the animation is pretty smooth. +/- I might like the overall feel of Absolution, but sometimes I think this kind of tone is a bit off for Hitman. Way too cinematic for me, everything's is just so shiny (especially 47's head), in oppose of the dark/gritty atmosphere of the first 4 (especially Contracts). The effects is a bit overdone at times.   Gameplay: 7/10    +The ability to take cover, and subduing enemy from cover, auto dragging after garroting someone, hiding a body in closet are some really welcomed addition. The UI is greatly improved, less obtrusive and more intuitive , though I never had a problem with the previous one, Absolution just modernized it in the right way. +/-: The disguise system. In a way, it's nice to see that 47 isn't completely safe when he's in disguise, when people question 'Is this a new guy? Have I seen him before?', it adds up the realism, but in quite many cases, it becomes an annoyance where you just can't concentric on observing the various possibility a map can offer, and it brings up the flaws on Hitman Absolution.. +/- Oh wait, the scoring system. It's an overhaul that no one asked for, OK, the leaderboard thing is cool, and brings up a nice competitive heat. And the obtrusive-ness depend on how 'perfectionist' the player is. As for me, it's a double edged sword, at one side, It pumps my inner 'Perfect Assassin' soul, but in the other side, I don't like my definition of a Perfect Assassin is dictated by a score. Like: 'OK, I'll shoot this guy with a Sniper Rifle, perfect spot, no one's looking' *shoot poor guy* *Gets 20,000 points* 'OH GOD I SHOULD USE THE GARROTE WIRE FOR THE EXTRA 7500!' *Spent extra 45 minutes to get past guards*.  - Linear map design. Absolution might have an amazing attention in detail on the map's texture, props, and all. But detail in term of gameplay and layout, it's rarely to be found here. Gone the blueprint, majestic, open-world playground, replaced by a map that is designed for the sake of the progression of the story. The less obvious pathway is actually obvious in comparison of previous title. There's an entrance, you can go by 2 way, front or side, there's a property, we make it stand out, it means it can be used to kill the victim, and there's an exit, guarded by annoyingly lots of some patrolling and stand-still guards. Of course, it's not true for all levels, Chinatown, Blackwater, and Street of Hope are the stand out there.  - - The checkpoint system, the biggest sin of Absolution. THAT AT TIMES-OBSCURELY-PLACED-DAMNED-CHECKPOINT. I hate it, with a passion. They replace the perfect traditional saving system, where I can save anytime-anywhere, when I want to experiment things, that I know it could go wrong, they replace it with this..thing... And everytime I reload a checkpoint the enemies that I previously subdued magically re-appear, is this secretly a resurrection tool or something? This thing..is just.. I'm speechless, for no good reason..at all..   Sound: 8.5/10   + The voice acting is a huge step up from previous title. The characters feels more alive, and adds up a bit of emotion, and overall the sounds / sound effects is fine for me. +/- Great, but didn't quite match up the previous title. Jesper Kyd departure does make a noticeable impact to the musical tone, though I'm not attentive enough when it comes to soundtrack, but I know the OST is pretty great when I come to YouTube just to listen to it. Absolution, doesn't give that feeling to me, or at least, not much.   Story: 7,5.10    + I like how the story is presented, in cinematic perspective. The progression, some twist, and clearer sense of plot and decent character development. A smoothly flowing and intriguing story.  - I like the story, I like the presentation, but I don't like the type of narrative, the way it's told. It's trying to be dramatic, and it becomes out of place most of the times. I like the 'Get in, assassinate, get out' kind of narrative, while the story is told through the briefing and short opening/middle/ending scene. It just feels like a more proper assassin story.    Overall/Enjoyment: 7.5/10     Hitman Absolution is an ambitious entry of the game, over-ambitious perhaps, and it's quite obvious. And ambition can result something like Absolution. A game with really high production value and very polished, yet tends to overdo everything, to the point that it forgot what it is in the first place, but it's awfully familiar in many elements. My review might seems harsh, especially in the gameplay section, but trust me.. it's still a fun game. A sneak-em-up action/adventure with a lot of decent, yet limited assassination, a, at times, way too strict sandbox game. A more 'methodical' Hitman, rather than the 'imaginative' one. But, it's still an awesome game, but it's a 'just good' Hitman game. It's still a fun and solid game, with a deep and rewarding stealth system, though IO's attempt to keep every Hitman entry fresh is riddled with few bad design choices this time.

Hitman Absolution is the fifth entry in Io Interactive's Hitman series of stealth assassination games. Since the series began, the developers have always iterated heavily with each instalment, never being content to leave game elements as they are when improvements can be found. Absolution is no exception, and feels smoother, more attractive, and more compelling than even 2006's superb Blood Money.  Players that see the Hitman series purely as a series of largely unconnected, discrete challenges always focused on assassination may be disappointed with the new approach, but for everyone else Absolution is probably the ultimate Hitman game yet. Agent 47 is as deadly as ever, but he is now both hunter and hunted, reliant on his wits and what he can scavenge from the environment to succeed. This time around it isn't just duty that drives 47, but a strong and coherent plot that makes every hair-raising infiltration and carefully-planned kill feel personal and important.  Gripping from start to finish and polished until it shines, Hitman: Absolution is a truly brilliant game and a must for any fan of stealth and third-person action games.

The Hitman series has continually challenged players with tracking and assassinating various targets across the world, while providing multiple routes in which to accomplish the particular tasks at hand. Absolution marks the first true entry in the current generation of games built upon its powerful, in-house built Glacier 2 graphics engine. In addition, the gameplay has been altered with the introduction of new features associated with the Instinct and Contracts modes.  Set directly after the events of the previous game, Hitman: Blood Money, Absolution tasks Agent 47 with tracking down his series handler Diana Burnwood after she goes rogue and reveals the agency's identity to the public. The new Agency director Benjamin Travis orders Agent 47 to kill Diana and capture a teenage girl by the name of Victoria that has been under her care. Upon reading a letter left from Diana, the narrative spirals into a chaotic set of events interwoven with Agent 47 being hunted by both the police and a cast of villains that aim to capture the mysterious Victoria from him. The majority of levels are set in various exterior and interior locales in Chicago and a small town in South Dakota.  A major contrast from past games in the series is the addition of entire level sequences that focus on evading the police while reaching a designated exit. In these particular sequences, players aren't even provided with particular targets to assassinate that results in the gameplay resembling a generic shooter versus a Hitman game. Some sections feel eerily similar to the gameplay of IO Interactive's past Kane and Lynch series of games. The levels that do offer particular targets to assassinate and multiple routes in which to accomplish that task are the most memorable of the narrative and beg for multiple playthroughs.  Each playthrough of a level is continually scored based on each action taken by the player from killing civilians to being detected by patrolling enemies. The game has a way in which it wants the player to complete each level and any deviations result in the loss of points. Compared with recent games in the Hitman series, Absolution includes far too many linear paths and evade the police scenarios that result in an overall more restrictive experience.  The major change in the Hitman gameplay formula in Absolution revolves around the addition of the Instinct mode. Instinct in the game is displayed through a meter that regenerates overtime through various actions taken. There are a variety of uses that involve Instinct mode from scanning the environment for enemies and their movement, which is similar to the detective mode in Batman Arkham Asylum, to a quick shot kill system, which is similar to the mark and execute feature in Splinter Cell: Conviction. While both are not original concepts, they work exceptionally well in surveying the environment and when in difficult situations that require a quick takedown of multiple enemies.  The major aspect of Instinct mode that will cause some frustration with players is how it handles disguises. NPCs in the game can detect that the player is lying about their identity if wearing the same disguise, with the example that other police officers would be able to spot someone new in their ranks. To counter this, Agent 47 can either wear disguises that aren't of the same group of NPCs or use Instinct mode to hide their true identity. Unfortunately, Instinct mode when used for disguises drains at an alarmingly quick rate that makes it useful for only brief scenarios. In later levels, disguises feel completely useless when nearly all of the NPCs are of the same group and can quickly discover Agent 47.  Aside from the new Instinct mode and cover system, nearly all of the Hitman series basics return with the infamous fiber wire and dual Silverballer pistols. Along with a host of other weaponry from pistols and shotguns to rifles and explosives, Agent 47 has the ability to utilize various weapons and staged accidents located throughout levels. Makeshift weapons appear in the form of small objects like knives, hammers, and even bongs. While some of them aren't the most practical to use in combat situations, they serve as great alternatives to when a more specialized approach is required for a certain situation.  Following with the tradition of past games in the series, Agent 47 has the ability to utilize conveniently-placed staged accidents around the level that range from a hoisted car on a lift to food items that are ripe for poisoning. While some staged accidents are simple to put in motion, others require carefully-planned timing and execution to perform the perfect assassination. Absolution stays true to the Hitman series by continually providing players with a near endless amount of options in assassinating targets from going completely Rambo style to a more subtle approach with a knife stab in the back.  Levels completed in the campaign mode can later be played through in the Contracts mode that has players setting their own targets and selecting loadouts of unlocked disguises/weapons. The points earned in the both modes can be used to unlock additional disguises, weapons, and gun modifications ranging from silencers to extended clips. Contracts mode introduces the Hitman series first online feature in that the scenarios that players devise can be uploaded online for others to download and play. When creating a custom contract, players walk through a level and assassinate whom they wish and with what disguise and weapon they feel is right for the particular task. When the target eliminated, players then rush to an exit point to complete the level. With the level complete and statistics tracked for the time taken for both assassinating the target and reaching the exit, players can then proceed with uploading the contract for other players to compete in beating their score. Players that use the particular disguise and weapon that the creator did in their original playthrough will earn additional points when completing the contract.  Contracts mode seems to be the developer's answer to the restrictive campaign levels and escape from the police sections. The Contracts mode is clearly not the perfect solution for fans that were looking for similar gameplay from the previous Hitman game, but it's a step in the right direction considering that players can select their own disguise and weapon loadout. Contracts mode will be interesting to watch as more players upload their specialized combination of levels, targets, disguises, and weapon loadouts.  IO Interactive's Glacier 2 engine can be summarized with 1 word: stunning. From the massively-rendered crowds to the detailed interior/exterior environments, Absolution never ceases to amaze with visuals that beg to be set to max. Absolution debuts as the first real entry of the Hitman series in the high-definition era of gaming and succeeds at trumping nearly all of the current game releases. The sound effects and most notably the music succeed at impressing with loud and bold gunfire and mesmerizing classical scores. The soundtrack composed by Thomas Bärtschi fits the atmosphere of Absolution perfectly whether it may be a hectic gun battle or silent takedown.  Absolution marks a bold new direction for the Hitman series that focuses less on player freedom and more on telling a defined narrative. While the levels and poorly-implemented Instinct mode are sure to anger and frustrate fans of the series, Absolution still succeeds at providing an entertaining and most importantly, engaging gameplay experience that is difficult to put down until the credits roll. Both the expansive Contracts mode and stunning graphical overhaul help in overcoming the issues associated with the restrictive campaign levels.

Hitman: Absolution is quite difficult to review in my usual less-than-200-words. Let me put up front that I've truly enjoyed most Hitman games and Blood Money might even be one of the better games ever made. Let's start with the good: Absolution is great fun. Much like before, many ways and many possibilities leading to that one perfect kill. Contracts mode is a welcome addition, the graphics are smooth, the story is decent, the controls are fluid and there's a ♥♥♥♥load to do. Someone with OCD could easily spend 300 hours completing every single challenge. Overall it's a very good game, just not 100% a Hitman game.  Which brings me to the bad. Now, I don't really mind the new direction. Most new gimmicks work well and add a certain level of fun or depth to the game. But adding a Superman-like X-Ray vision feels wrong, whereas peeking through keyholes is no longer possible. Disguises are fairly ineffective and it is also no longer possible to 'clear' the area and do your thing, as there are respawns... or 'backup', as they like to call it. This does bite the 'do it your way' theory in the ♥♥♥, for stealth is the only viable option.  Also the game is not flawless. The checkpoint system is utter crap, as it doesn't save your progress properly - dumping you in a fully respawned map every time you load a checkpoint. Civilians 'spotting' you (hurting your score and possible challenges) after you've just saved them from a certain death is also the perfect gratitude. I've also had my loading screen freeze a dozen times now.   I'd like to put this one under the 'Max Payne 3 effect'. The game is awesome, but tends to forget what made us love its predecessors.   Long story short, it looks like Hitman, but doesn't play like Hitman. Therefore the emphasis is too much on stealth gameplay, often better comparable to Splinter Cell. In essence this is not a bad thing. Only to the die-hard fans, which I am not. For that I am not, I can forgive the developers for this new direction. In conclusion all I can do is praise the game: its very daring and -almost- really good.   The only true murderers here, are expectations.    + Fun, fun, fun + Possibly hundreds of hours of gameplay + Overall, a great game – just not very Hitman-like   - Bugs involving challenges are infuriating - Terrible checkpoint system - Less freedom - Small maps don't work so well - … not very Hitman-like  8.5/10

A strange and unusual game when compared to its peers. This  Hitman  game was released in the late life of the seventh generation of consoles i.e. Xbox 360, PS3. (Blood Money was released in the early life of the 7th generation) As such you can probably guess what gameplay and graphics are like.  Graphics  do  improve if you have a higher spec graphics card (but won't be anything like 8th generation games). In fact, cutscenes rendered by your own machine will look much better than pre-rendered cutscenes.  Gameplay is rather intuitive, although AI can be a bit dopey at times. You must proceed along areas where the objective is mostly to pass through an area undetected, using disguises and distractions to aid you. When the game finally does get you to eliminate targets, things get interesting. You can make things look like an accident and watch as the NPCs are shocked and scared, or you can take firm action and garrot, stab, bludgeon, shoot or blow up your target either quietly or as loud as you can get. The game's focus on stealth does sometimes fail itself, as certain missions are next to impossibe to complete quietly and would require you to go loud to take out as many hostiles as possible.  As a third person shooter, it's relatively solid, but as I've said the stealth can sometimes fail and going loud won't be an option. NPCs can't see you at a cetain distance, but can see you if you're garroting a guard or otherwise. Certain actions will raise suspicion, others will not. Crouching is considered suspicious, as is running and so is pressing up against a wall.  The story of the game makes little sence and often involves elements which have probably been thought of by some deviant at IO Interactive (I am referencing the Agency BDSM nuns with one RPG to share, and other weird stuff), but that's not really why you're playing a  Hitman  game.  The contracts feature does bring the game back to its firm grounding where it's as simple as just eliminating a target in the best way possible.

Agent 47 doesn't begin Hitman: Absolution with amnesia, but the six years that have passed since we last took control of him in Blood Money do seem to have dulled his creators' recollections of what made him so popular in the first place. Hitman: Absolution is a slick, responsive and mechanically confident game - and on occasions it's one of the most satisfying stealth games in a year that already includes Dishonored - but a range of compromises to Hitman tradition mean it's still going to rub some people up the wrong way.  Hitman is a simple concept: someone gives you a target, or targets, and you take them out. The genius of it is the way the designers let you do that. It's not just about deciding whether to sneak past people or get into a gun-fight - it's about slowly tracking the movements of people through large environments and observing the ways you can manipulate them and their surroundings to bring about their downfall. Perhaps you place explosives where you know they'll wander, or maybe you arrive just in time to nudge them over a railing into a deserted alleyway, and often you do all this dressed in borrowed clothes that conceal your identity from all but the most detailed investigation.  Hitman: Absolution includes all of that stuff, and on the higher difficulty levels it leaves you to figure a lot of it out on your own. You sneak or roam in disguise through police stations, courthouses, dilapidated mob-run hotels, maize-covered farmland, factories and science labs, teasing out details about your target from overheard conversations and useful objects left on shelves or in poorly guarded rooms. Then you formulate a plan and try to pull it off. If you're new to the series or just a bit rusty, you might begin by simply trying to find a few moments alone with your target and your trusty fibre wire, but before long you're on the lookout for more elaborate and creative executions: self-immolation, industrial accidents, tainted drugs and the sudden, unexpected failure of previously reliable overhead rigging.  Feeling your way into these unusual scenarios is surprisingly comfortable thanks to robust controls and clear rules about how things work. Movement and cover systems match the fluent standards of modern third-person games, crowds and guards only find you suspicious if you're behaving that way, disguises don't work on people wearing the same get-up, and crates, cupboards and dumpsters can hold two bodies, one of which can be you. A new Instinct system (heavily regulated on higher difficulties) allows Agent 47 to see the movements of NPCs and targets through walls and highlights interactive objects in the environment, while allowing you to briefly evade detection by people who would otherwise see through your disguise. It refills when you perform actions that the game's scoring system considers admirable, like hiding bodies from sight.  The scoring system - how nice to play a big game in 2012 that gives you a score at the end of each level, by the way - encourages creative solutions and sort of discourages extracurricular murder, although it's a mischievous companion, and many of the optional objectives in your notebook hint at ways you might consider dispatching your target's entourage as well as him or her. It's impossible to complete all these tasks in a single play-through - you can't exactly wear every available disguise in a level and play through it only dressed in your agency suit, for example - and they can be ignored if you prefer to remain utterly undetected and only lay hands on your assigned victim.  There are plenty of times in Hitman: Absolution when all these systems come together in ghoulishly delicious harmony. Stalking through a cornfield dressed as a scarecrow, picking off machine-gun-toting goons and then stringing yourself up on a wooden frame to hide in plain sight; dropping a heavy piano lid on the head of a musically curious henchman without anyone noticing; distracting policemen by leaving a cash-filled safe open in a busted drug den; or turning the tools of several mad scientists' trade against them in gruesomely hilarious ways. Played as a kind of grimly amusing series of cautionary tales where you skulk through the shadows implementing the caution, Absolution is enormous fun.

Oh boy... where to begin? Yes, this game is fun. Yes, I love the 'blend in' kind of stealth as opposed to the 'don't be seen' kind. Yes, I can enjoy the more linear levels, as opposed to the sandbox ones. Both have their advantages: the sandbox allows you to be more creative, but it can be very overwhelming, especially if you have to reset. Ah, there we go. Resetting. I have one problem with this game. Not the disguise recogtnition system - which is a very nice and realistic idea they unfortunately couldn't get around without the instinct system. Not the instinct itself: 47 covering his face with a cap might look stupid, but managing that resource bar is another layer of strategy, even if an exploitable one(it's easy to quickly tap into the instinct when you're about to get recognized and watch as your watcher's suspicion indicator resets); point shooting, on the other hand, seems unecessary - it's not the kind of game where I should be shooting a room full of people, which is a shame because 47's Silverballers look so cool they are begging to be used. - but it's there and it looks cool, if you want to use it; the highlighting key elements is useful in telling apart what's scenery and what's a potential deathtrap. No, my problem is with the scoring system. It's what turns this game from a fun, if slightly limited - would say, not entirely without reason, the Blood Money enthusiasts -, sadistic workshop into an exercise of trial-and-error frustration in search of one of the optimal methods the developers designed into the level. No more of the free approach 'I'll have that guard chase me into the garage, climb out by the roof and get into the door he was guarding' stuff. You get spotted, you mess up in a tiny way, and you have that negative score jeopardizing your whole run, regardless of how well or how brilliantly you manage to contain or even take profit from the situation. Instead, you reload your checkpoint and try to search for that one air duct the level designer put somewhere that will coincidentally end up somewhere the AI is programmed to trigger an event... say, lighting a cigarette near some convenient gas pump. It's less about creativity, more about finding the optimal solution, which, as far as I know, is not what this series was ever about. Maybe I want to use a silenced sniper to kill patrols, knocking their bodies off a bridge? Well, shame on me, 'cause my score will never reach my friend's, who preferred to go for the Silent Assassin bonus.Why should I be punished for using the many tools the game gave me to kill? Instead, it will slap my hand and make me shimmy from the edges around said bridge if I ever want to go for a good score. I don't even want to explore to find alternative methods(some of which are mind boggling, if funny. Rigging a power line so a guy gets shocked while ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥? Scattering a wrestler's guards by stealing his... teddy bear?), I just want to find the first solution that will get me through the level. As for the story... yeah, it isn't great. It's cliché, it's predictable in 95% of its run. I do, however, enjoy how it provided an opportunity for 47 to be portrayed as a more humane, relatable character, even if sometimes he would make me bang my head on my desk. Showing your face in front of a crowd before snapping the neck of your target? I thought we were going for the subtle and unnoticed approach.  It's not a bad game, don't get me wrong. I had fun with it. Getting through the levels is fun, especially when I could manage to explore without setting off some score penalty. But there was a whole lot of frustration about trying to figure out and execute a puzzle in its most perfect details, not about exploring and coming up with a plan I would adapt on the fly. Again, not a bad game, just one that went the opposite way of my expectations.

It's like Dishonored, if Dishonored had less story and more restrictive levels, but those levels are short enough to encourage repeat playthroughs right away to try and get closer to 'full completion'.  Very pretty game and a rather generic story. The levels so far have felt very believable, with reasonably human-like behavior from NPCs and entertaining overheard conversations between guards. If you like the approach of 'let me try again, but this time poison his food instead of making him explode', you might enjoy this game. If you blast through levels to get to the end , the game's design will disappoint - the foes aren't generally challenging enough and the shorter level design means your game will end quickly (and probably be unsatisfying, since some levels end with the killing happening in a cutscene).

Absolution is both good and bad. If you're a purist with the franchise, you may not like it. If you've never played another one before, it'll probably feel awesome playing it.  It has a decent story and the graphics are nice, but coming from having spent years playing all the other games as they were released, I can't say I'm necessarily pleased with where Square Enix is taking the franchise.  Personal peeves: The ease with which people wearing the same type of outfit as you can see through your disguise. This makes even less sense when you're wearing a disguise that covers your entire body and about half of your head and face. 'Instinct' drains very, VERY quickly when being used to blend in, which made me feel like the game was promoting more of a stealth-based Splinter Cell or Metal Gear type of gameplay. In all of the other Hitman titles, guards could see through your disguise--provided you were acting like a lunatic, or carrying weapons not befitting your outfit. That said, they didn't have some preturnatural sixth sense to just say 'Hey, that guy's not one of us!'. When you're dealing with massive areas and dozens upon dozens of employees in a specific outfit, there's no real way that every single person could pinpoint you as being out of place that quickly. Wasn't a fan of the pretty much forced stealth based, take cover behind every object you can gameplay when that has traditionally not been how the games play out.  Aside from that, my only other real complaint is the level layouts. I can't really explain it without making it sound too confusing, but I found the level layouts to be really different from the other games in the series and didn't like the way that felt.  So that's it. I'm just ♥♥♥♥♥ing because it wasn't like the other games. It was good enough for me to give a full play-through of, and still a fun game besides that, so I recommend it despite my own issues. Enjoy!

I finished the story mode for Hitman:Absolution and one of the core reasons was that there was something that drew me back. However overall it's not enough for me to recommend the game, or to want to play it again. Essentially I just ended up grinding it out.  Pros: 1. Graphics and audio. Reasoonably well done. A little too much bloom, and the cutscenes are jarringly sub-par compared to the in-game graphics but nonetheless it looks the Hitman part. For the record, I have a medium rig. 2. Some of the Gameplay. I think when it works, this was the games strongest point. When playing in crowds or having lots of easily accessible hiding spots Hitman was quite enjoyable. Not unlike watching a guilty pleasure B-grade action movie.  Cons: - When it doesn't work though. OMG then it's obvious; 1. Cutscene story inconsistency - what's the point of being a super-assassin (the story says you are), and playing like one (making sure not to make stupid mistakes), when the protaganist just throws it out the door at every cutscene? It was like a slap in the face whenever he kept making rookie mistakes and then you, have to get him out of the predicament. 2. Recon - Ugh. So I said that it had areas that worked. But overall, it was just bad. Instead of being able to survey the location, choose the best option(s) available and to prepare (with costumes, weapons etc) you were simply just dumped at the beginning of each location in full assassin uniform glory.  3. Disguises - So you can grab a disguise, that's great! Problem is that the second you do this, any NPC who have the same uniform are onto you. So you spend more time hiding from them. (also, can't he afford a wig or beard?). Which leads me to; 4. NPCs - The game makes you spend all of your time hiding out of the line of sight of any NPC. Honestly, this thing gets my panties in a bunch. When I think of Hitman, I think of someone who is supposed to literally clean house discretly and professionally. Instead we have to march around constantly changing disguises and either NOT killing anyone who isnt our target, or just passifying them and then hiding their body. The best in the franchise, Hitman: Absolution brings Agent 47 into a streamlined, satisfying league of his own. Others may sing paeans to Blood Money's non-linearity and Silent Assassin's score (both series highs, respectively), but Absolution boasts the most responsive and satisfying gameplay. The cover-based stealth and multiple discrete mission paths recall the excellent Deus Ex: Human Revolution, and part of the fun of each level is following the breadcrumbs the designers left for players to find and act on - the gun shop level, Birdie's Gift, is an outstanding example. The story comprises the black ops pulp and stereotypes we've come to expect from the franchise, though it's all presented impeccably. Chuckle-worthy black humor abounds, even if it stoops to juvenile levels on occasion.  No, Absolution's not perfect. The score system can at times be infuriating: it's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that you get a 'Spotted' malus while firing multiple bullets through an isolated guard's faceplate. And without getting into major spoilers, the game inexplicably reverses wodges of the plot in its last five seconds. It's an infuriating way to end the series' narrative high point.  Yet, all in all, the game plays very well, looks gorgeous, and sounds great. Buy if you at all giggle at the prospect of electrocuting a man through his urine stream.

Anyway, I will still recommend this game for all stealth fans and it's very much worth buying for all fans of the genre.

Shitman: Abortion was developed by IO Interactive and released by Square Enix in November 2012. It was the then-latest iteration in the Hitman franchise. For those unfamiliar with Hitman, all of the games in the series had centred upon the eponymous Hitman (Agent 47) being placed in a level with a wide variety of obstacles and enemies, with the player being tasked with taking control of 47 and eliminating the target. The games allowed for a wide variety of playstyles, but the most succesful and satisfying routes were usually found in learning the layout of the map, the behaviour of the NPCs, the hazards present, and eliminating the target through use of the environment. This formula was perfected in 2006's  Hitman: Blood Money .   Having loved Blood Money, and having felt IO had perfected the formula, a lot of the fanbase were eagerly anticipating Absolution. All IO needed to do was give us more of what they had did in Blood Money; more levels with a variety of solutions and an immense amount of complexity. What we got was a linear action game with a few obligatory assasination levels that were crippled by the inclusion of new mechanics designed to streamline the game but only succeeded in making it frustrating to impossible to play the game without them. The game was gorgeous - and still is - and ran on relatively modest hardware, but other than that we were given a vapid experience that bore no resemblence to prior Hitman titles. It failed as a Hitman game, and unless was willing to play on a lower difficulty with 'instinct mode', it failed as an enjoyable game.
